traits.calling_and_background: Introduced as a Galilean fisherman called by Jesus from his nets to become a fisher of people, leaving his work immediately.
traits.role_among_twelve: Regularly named first among the Twelve and functions as their spokesperson, present at key private moments like healings and the transfiguration.
traits.confession_and_misunderstanding: Confesses Jesus as the Christ at Caesarea Philippi but is sharply rebuked as Satan for rejecting the necessity of the suffering Son of Man.
traits.failure_and_denial: Boasts of loyalty yet denies Jesus three times during the trial sequence, fulfilling Jesus’s prediction and weeping when he realizes what he has done.
traits.post_resurrection_note: The young man at the tomb instructs the women to tell the disciples and Peter that Jesus goes before them to Galilee, implying continued significance but not narrating restoration.

traits.calling_and_background: Called with his brother Andrew from their fishing work on the Sea of Galilee to follow Jesus as disciples.
traits.role_among_twelve: Consistently listed first and singled out for special experiences and sayings, marking him as a chief disciple.
traits.confession_and_primacy: Confesses Jesus as the Messiah, the Son of the living God, and is addressed as Peter the rock upon which Jesus will build his church, entrusted with the keys of the kingdom and binding-loosing authority.
traits.faith_and_weakness: Briefly walks on water toward Jesus but sinks in fear, and later is rebuked as a stumbling block for opposing Jesus’s passion predictions.
traits.denial_and_after: Denies Jesus three times despite earlier protestations but goes out and weeps bitterly; the risen Jesus later commissions the Eleven (including Peter) with universal mission, leaving his individual restoration implicit.

traits.calling_and_background: Introduced as Simon, a fisherman whose boat Jesus uses before the miraculous catch that leads him to leave everything and follow.
traits.role_among_twelve: Emerges as a leading disciple, renamed Peter and included in the inner circle present at significant events such as the transfiguration.
traits.warning_and_denial: Jesus predicts that Satan has demanded to sift him like wheat but that Jesus has prayed for his faith; despite this, Peter denies Jesus three times before the rooster crows.
traits.restoration_hint: Jesus charges him to strengthen his brothers once he has turned back, signaling anticipated restoration and leadership beyond the failure.
traits.resurrection_witness_tradition: Luke preserves a brief report that the Lord has appeared to Simon, marking him as an early resurrection witness without narrating the encounter.

traits.name_and_identity: Introduced as Simon son of John, whom Jesus renames Cephas (Peter), highlighting a new identity linked to his role.
traits.relationship_to_jesus: Frequently appears alongside the beloved disciple in scenes of intimacy and tension, such as the last supper, the high priest’s courtyard, and the empty tomb.
traits.confession_and_loyalty_claims: Affirms that Jesus has the words of eternal life and insists that he will lay down his life for Jesus, claims that are undercut by his subsequent denial.
traits.denial_and_interrogation: Denies being Jesus’s disciple three times in the high priest’s courtyard, paralleling but distinct from the Synoptic denial narratives.
traits.reinstatement_and_future: The risen Jesus questions his love three times beside the sea, commands him to feed and tend his flock, and hints at a future martyrdom by which he will glorify God.

traits.leadership_in_jerusalem: Acts opens with Peter taking initiative among the disciples, overseeing the replacement of Judas and speaking on behalf of the group.
traits.pentecost_and_preaching: Serves as the primary interpreter of the Pentecost event, delivering major speeches that frame Jesus’s death and resurrection in terms of scripture and divine plan.
traits.miracle_work_and_conflict: Performs healings and signs reminiscent of Jesus’s ministry and confronts opposition from the Jerusalem authorities.
traits.mission_and_inclusion: Plays a central role in the Cornelius episode, where his vision and visit help legitimize Gentile inclusion without full Torah observance.
traits.narrative_exit: Dominates the early chapters but gradually recedes as Paul becomes the main narrative focus, last appearing prominently after his escape from Herod’s prison.

traits.name_and_status: Referred to as Cephas, recognized as a leading figure among the Jerusalem apostles.
traits.pillar_role: Counted among the reputed pillars of the Jerusalem community, associated with James and John as leaders.
traits.agreement_and_mission: In Galatians, Paul portrays an agreement in which he and Barnabas would go to the Gentiles while Cephas and the others focus on the circumcised.
traits.conflict_at_antioch: Paul recounts confronting Cephas publicly in Antioch over withdrawal from table fellowship with Gentiles, using him as an example of inconsistency with the gospel.
traits.reputation_in_communities: In 1 Corinthians, some believers identify themselves with Cephas as a factional leader alongside Paul and Apollos, reflecting his broader authority and influence.
